title: Brexit: Corbyn told to back new EU referendum or lose millions of supporters
text:
Jeremy Corbyn is under pressure to back a hard Brexit even if it means losing millions of his own supporters, following pressure from his own campaign in the EU referendum. An analysis of online sentiment by Bridge has found that 62% of Labour activists opposed a hard Brexit while 50% believed it would result in leaving the European Union. On Friday, 63% of Labour supporters asked if they would back a hard Brexit or a soft Brexit were it to happen, compared with 18% who said they would definitely not back a hard Brexit and 4% who said they would. Annual surveys published by Vote Leave over the past six months have found that none of the UK’s 86 or so political parties had a manifesto commitment to a hard Brexit or a soft Brexit. A new, joint report by the Sunday Times and Britain First to be released on Monday will reveal that nearly all the party’s activists want a “hard Brexit”. Both parties have complained that pro-hard-Brexit “Britishness” was portrayed in the campaign, but the analysis by Bridge shows that 59% of all local parties’ online profiles from 2015 to 2017 want to see Britain remain in the European Union. Jonathan Khalil, the report’s co-author, said: “The outcome of the EU referendum clearly exposed a people’s desire for Britain to leave the European Union but with a choice, union or departure. “We need to argue for an alternative to the Conservative government’s Brexit package based on free trade, market access and indeed freedom from Brussels. Instead we have a Conservative government which has removed the Chequers agreement and is planning to offer up the precise opposite – instead of full membership of the European Union, we will be blocked from free trade, customs union and single market.”
The analysis found that 35% of the Conservative and 22% of Labour volunteers had a raft of pro-Brexit promises, from a strong trade relationship with the EU to an alternative to the government’s Brexit deal. The research, the only analysis published by Bridge before the research came out, will almost certainly fuel Labour protests against the shadow Brexit secretary, Keir Starmer, and other ministers accusing them of fighting for a hard Brexit because they have nothing else to run on. “It is interesting to note that, whilst some people’s stated concerns are eurosceptic, many people’s concerns are that while we are ending the European Union, we are not leaving the UK,” Khalil said. “Interestingly, the public discussion on membership of the European Union focuses on the European Union in its totality. The idea that when your country is leaving it is going to be fine, well that is not how people really feel about the European Union.”
Bridge, run by the London thinktank the London Group, said the figures reflected people’s shared perspective that Britain would likely be better off outside the EU than inside it. Khalil said that 23% of Labour online profiles chose a hard Brexit while 15% chose a soft Brexit and just 3% responded clearly. Some 62% of the people who responded strongly said they would definitely vote to leave the EU and 16% would definitely not. Khalil said that there was no evidence of a great public divide on Europe in the Labour party, but that the party could challenge what people mean when they say the EU. “The public can say we want to be outside the EU, in other words, we don’t want the European Union. But is it an option? You know, why is it being described as an option?”
Starmer, the shadow foreign secretary, told the Guardian: “If you tell people they can’t say ‘no’ when they say Brexit, then they are going to walk away. People are saying ‘no’ because they don’t want to be on the ‘no’ side of a decision.”
A Vote Leave spokesman said: “The anti-EU far-right is determined to make a mockery of the referendum and won’t stop when it comes to trying to block Brexit. It would be utterly irrational and irresponsible of anyone to effectively pretend there’s a huge vote of people against Brexit. “We know that Labour members are overwhelmingly anti-EU and most believe Brexit could have brought benefits to Britain’s economy – and this is not an attempt to undermine the referendum.”
• This article was amended on Monday 13 April 2019 because it had mistakenly referred to Labour’s online profiles from 2015 to 2017, rather than 2015 and 2016. The post was updated on Monday at 11.59am to correct the error.
